heading: shares of oracle soaracle
subheading: the database software giant has a great day: its shares surge more than 13 percent thanks to better earnings than estimates.
author: reuters
text: san francisco -- shares of oracle, the world's biggest developer of database software, surged 13.4 percent on wednesday, after the company's second-quarter earnings handily beat wall street estimates. oracle reported net income of us$384 million, or 26 cents a share, up from net income of $274 million, or 19 cents a share a year ago. according to first call/thomson financial, the consensus on wall street was 22 cents a share.shares of the redwood shores, california-based company jumped 10-1/2 to 87-7/16 in very active trading on the nasdaq.salomon smith barney analyst neil herman said that oracle crushed his earnings estimates and the consensus estimate.herman said oracle's licensing revenues, up almost 18 percent year-over-year, were stronger than he expected and expenses came in below his expectations. service revenues were below his expectations, but he noted that oracle is focusing on partnering with consulting firms to drive software license sales."oracle is clearly cutting the fat but is determined to continue to build the muscle," herman wrote in a note to clients. "we believe the pipeline of business remains extremely strong going forward."herman said he raised his price target on oracle to $100, up from $75 previously, and raised earnings estimates for fiscal 2000 to $1.15 a share from $1.05 previously, and for fiscal 2001 to $1.45 a share from $1.40 previously.deutsche banc alex. brown analyst james moore upgraded oracle to a strong buy from a buy.merrill lynch analyst chris shilakes raised his 12-month price target on oracle to $100 from $85 previously.shilakes noted that operating margins in the quarter exploded and licensing revenues accelerated, leading him to raise his fiscal 2000 earnings estimates to $1.14 a share from $1.07 a share previously, and fiscal 2001 estimate to $1.40 from $1.30.copyright
